thread.title: Steve Spurrier's top 10 games at South Carolina

title: Steve Spurrier's top 10 games at South Carolina
text: Email Facebook @jeff_fromthepc Oct 16 2015 12:01 am South Carolina quarterback Stephen Garcia celebrates after the Gamecocks' win over No. 1 Alabama at Williams-Brice Stadium in 2010. (AP/File photo) 1. South Carolina 35, Alabama 21 Date: Oct. 9, 2010 Why it mattered: Ranked No. 19 in the nation, USC defeated a No. 1-ranked team for the first time in school history, knocking off the previously unbeaten Crimson Tide before 82,993 fans at Williams-Brice Stadium. “It's the biggest win ever at South Carolina,” said cornerback Stephon Gilmore. The HBC said: “We played to the end and looked up, and we'd beaten the No. 1 by two touchdowns.” USC players carry coach Steve Spurrier onto the field at The Swamp after defeating Florida, 36-14, in 2010. (AP Photo/John Raoux) 2. South Carolina 36, Florida 14 Date: Nov. 13, 2010 Why it mattered: Spurrier returned to Florida and led the Gamecocks to a 36-14 win over his alma mater to claim USC's first SEC East Division title. “It's crazy,” said USC running back Marcus Lattimore, “because it's actually happening.” The HBC said: “We don't have too many championships. We'll celebrate a little bit more than they do at Florida for a division (title).” South Carolina linebacker Marcquis Roberts celebrates after the Gamecocks' 31-17 victory over Clemson in 2013 at Williams-Brice Stadium. It was USC's fifth straight win against the Tigers. (Paul Zoeller/Staff) 3. South Carolina 31, Clemson 17 Date: Nov. 30, 2013 Why it mattered: South Carolina, ranked No. 10, defeated No. 6 Clemson for the fifth straight time, all five victories by double digits. It was the longest streak by one rival over the other since Clemson's seventh straight win in 1940. “To finish out with the seniors not losing to (Clemson) is special,” said quarterback Connor Shaw. The HBC said: “You're supposed to do that for bowl games,” Spurrier said after the players gave him a Gatorade bath. “Not for home victories.” Gamecock players Na'Shan Goddard and Jabari Levey (78) celebrate a 30-22 win over Florida in 2005 at Williams-Brice Stadium. (AP Photo/Perry Baker) 4. South Carolina 30, Florida 22 Date: Nov. 12, 2005 Why it mattered: USC was 7-3 but unranked when Spurrier's former team, No. 12 Florida, came to Columbia in 2005 in his first season with the Gamecocks. USC won its fifth straight SEC game and snapped a 14-game skid against Urban Meyer's Gators, signaling even better things to come. The HBC said: “I told you guys that we had a lot of history that we could set by coming to South Carolina. But I didn't think we'd set this much, this year.” Clemson coach Tommy Bowden talks with USC's Steve Spurrier before the Gamecocks' 31-28 victory in 2006. (AP Photo/Mary Ann Chastain) 5. South Carolina 31, Clemson 28 Date: Nov. 25, 2006 Why it mattered: USC went 7-5 overall and 5-3 in the SEC in Spurrier's first season in 2005, but lost to rival Clemson for the fourth straight time and eighth time in nine years. This win kicked off Spurrier's five-game win streak over Clemson. “It's the worst loss I ever had as a Tiger,” said Clemson lineman Dustin Fry. The HBC said: “We are dedicating this game to the South Carolina fans. They've lived with a lot of crap over the years, a lot more than me and a lot of our players.” USC defensive end Jadeveon Clowney makes his famous hit on Michigan running back Vincent Smith during the Gamecocks' 33-28 win in the 2012 Outback Bowl (AP/File photo) 6. South Carolina 33, Michigan 28 Date: Jan. 1, 2013 Why it mattered: A 33-28 win over No. 19 Michigan in the 2012 Outback Bowl capped an 11-2 season and was the second of four straight bowl wins for the Gamecocks. It's best recalled for Jadeveon Clowney's hit that blew off Vincent Smith's helmet and blew up the Internet. A pass to former Berkeley High School star Bruce Ellington won the game with 11 seconds left. X The HBC said: “We haven't won like that since I've been here.” South Carolina quarterback Connor Shaw (14) celebrates with teammates after a 27-24, double-overtime win at Missouri in 2013. (AP/File photo) 7. South Carolina 27, Missouri 24 (2OT) Date: Oct. 26, 2013 Why it mattered: No. 11 South Carolina was coming off a disappointing 23-21 loss at unranked Tennessee when the Gamecocks headed to the other Columbia to face No. 5 Missouri. Injured QB Connor Shaw came off the bench to rally USC from a 17-0 deficit, hitting 20 of 29 passes for 201 yards and three touchdowns. It was the first of six straight wins to end the season. The HBC said: “I went over and asked (Shaw), 'Can you play?' He said, sure. I said, 'We've got to make the move now.' It was do or die.” Freshman Marcus Lattimore had his breakout game in a 17-6 win over Georgia in 2010, running 37 times for 182 yards and two touchdowns. (AP Photo/Mary Ann Chastain) 8. South Carolina 17, Georgia 6 Date: Sept. 11, 2010 Why it mattered: Freshman running back Marcus Lattimore, who would become one of the most beloved Gamecocks in school history, had his breakout game. He carried 37 times for 182 yards and two TDs as No. 24 USC beat No. 22 Georgia, setting the stage for an SEC East title. “Well, it doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure out what the story of the game was,” Georgia coach Mark Richt said. The HBC said: “I think it's the first time ever that I shook hands with the opposing coach and he said, 'Steve, you've got a heck of a team.'” South Carolina quarterback Dylan Thompson filled in for an injured Connor Shaw and led the Gamecocks to a 27-17 win at Clemson in 2012. (Travis Bell/SIDELINE CAROLINA) 9. South Carolina 27, Clemson 17 Date: Nov. 24, 2012 Why it mattered: USC QB Connor Shaw was out with an injured foot, and Clemson was eager to snap what was then a three-game skid against the Gamecocks. But backup QB Dylan Thompson came off the bench to hit 23 of 41 passes for 310 yards and three TDs as USC won it's fourth straight in the series. The HBC said: “It seems like when we play Clemson, they don't play very well.” USC players give Steve Spurrier a celebratory Gatorade shower after a 30-13 win over Nebraska in the 2011 Capital One Bowl. (AP/File photo) 10. South Carolina 30, Nebraska 13 Date: Jan. 2, 2012 Why it mattered: USC had a 1-4 record in bowl games when the Gamecocks went to the Capital One Bowl to face No. 21 Nebraska at the end of the 2011 season. USC's win secured the first of three straight 11-2 seasons and marked the first of four straight bowl wins. The HBC said: “We're gonna have the alma mater, then all the Gamecocks can come down on the field and give a player a hug!” Keywords
